Good paper! It is now clear that HyperNEAT is indeed a very powerful 
type =
of NE algorithm. I believe that CPPNs are the best abstraction 
of developm=
ent found ever. And evolving and complexifying CPPNs with 
the NEAT method =
is one important part of the whole thing. Without it, 
CPPN evolution would=
 be a very limited technique. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kennet=
h Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Jason Gauci and I are pleased to share=
 with you new results with
> HyperNEAT  in our new paper to appear in the T=
wenty-Third AAAI
> Conference on Artificial Intelligence (2008), "A Case St=
udy on the
> Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in Machine Learning."  T=
he 
paper
> is available here:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
opti=
on=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=3D28#gauci.aaai08
> 
> Or for a=
 direct link:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/gauci_aaai08.pdf
> 
> Thi=
s paper demonstrates HyperNEAT in a more interesting domain
> (checkers) th=
an our introductory papers from last year and 
introduces
> an effective me=
thod to evolve substrates with a hidden layer.
> 
> Jason is also planning =
to release the source code for this domain,
> although we do not have an ex=
act release date at this time.
> 
> Those familiar with AI conferences will=
 also notice that in fact 
this
> paper appears in AAAI, which is more asso=
ciated with mainstream AI. 
> That they accepted a paper in this area is a =
hopeful sign that
> evolutionary computation and even indirect encoding can=
 in fact
> succeed in the larger AI community.  We are grateful to the 
rev=
iewers
> and chairs at AAAI for keeping an open mind.
> 
> Additional Hyper=
NEAT publications will be made available soon as 
well.
> 
> ken
>
